Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. SHERATON CENTER HOTEL, WASHINGTON D.C. - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The camera pans up to Bartlet on a monitor. He is speaking in front of many people.

Dialogues.Line: I get nervous around laws that fundamentally assume that Americans can't be trusted. We'd better have mandatory sentencing, because judges can't be trusted to disperse even-handed justice. The crowd applauds.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SECLUDED AREA - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Toby and Sam are in a secluded area watching the speech on monitors. The camera pans over Toby's shoulder to look down on a crowd. Bartlet is standing at the podium.

Dialogues.Line: We better have term limits, 'cause voters can't be trusted to recognize corruption. There's another round of applause from the crowd.

Oh, and by the way... I say, by the way. When the playing field is leveled and the process is fair and open, it turns out we have term limits. They're called elections. More applause. The camera pans through the crowd.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HOTEL PRESS AREA - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: C.J. is circulating the room full of reporters.

Dialogues.Line: The President ate his Wheaties this morning.

As a matter of fact, the President had a bowl of oatmeal this morning. He said it was something he's always wanted to try. [walks around the room and brushes by Danny] Folks, listen up. In a moment or two, the President is going to say something that's sure to get you all shouting my name at once. There'll be a full briefing tonight at the White House. C.J. circulates around the room. Danny approaches C.J.
C.J., look....
Yeah. You're not going to want to miss this. The crowd applauds again.
C.J., what is this? What's going on in there?
The President's going to throw his cap over the wall.
What does that mean?
You're about to find out.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: THE PODIUM - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: My father was very fond of the analogy of the Irish lads whose journey was blocked by a brick wall, seemingly too high to scale. Throwing their caps over the wall, the lads had no choice but to follow. How many times in the great history of our country have we come to a wall seemingly too high to scale only to throw our caps to the other side?
INT. A DARK ROOM - NIGHT The Senate Majority Leader is inside with his staff. Steve Onorato is watching Bartlet from a TV screen.
This was given to me by a constituent who read in Time Magazine that I like Cognac. The problem is, that this is Brandy and not Cognac. Anyone know the difference?
Senator?
The Cognac is supposed to come from the...
...The Cognac region of France. That's right.
Senator?
Steve, sit down with us over here, would you? The man's not going to say anything we're interested in.
I think he is.
What are you talking about?
Listen.
[on T.V.] Tomorrow... tomorrow morning, we're going to begin to change the way elections are supervised in this country.
He's going to name two finance reformers to the F.E.C.
What the hell are you talking about?
Listen.
You said it wasn't going to happen.
I was wrong.
You were wrong?
He's going to name... damn it! Somebody....
John Bacon...
John Bacon and Patty Calhoun.
You told him, they take on campaign finance reform, I roll out a legislative agenda that'll make his boss sit down and cry.
I made it very clear.
[on T.V.] I am proud to nominate John Branford Bacon and Patricia Calhoun to the Federal Election Commission.
Get him on the phone.
Who?
Josh Lyman. Get him on the phone. I'm going to reach down his throat and take out his lungs with an ice-cream scoop.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SHERATON HOTEL/MONITOR AREA - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh, Toby, and Sam are all decked out in tuxes.

Dialogues.Line: You're about to get a call.
Yeah.
Big call.
Yeah.
Powerful guy.
Yeah.
I'm just saying you're probably rocked back from your meeting last week.
A little.
They threatened you with a legislative agenda.
Yeah.
They made you feel powerless and you're a little off your game.
Yeah.
A little gun shy. In the background, a phone rings. Toby had sidled up by Sam.
Leave him alone.
I'm bucking him up.
Leave him alone.
You asked me to buck him up.
Now, I'm telling you to leave him alone.
Guys, I'm trying to watch this speech.
Josh.
The call?
On the cell. [hands him the cell phone]
Josh, if you need us, we're standing right here. Josh turns away to answer the call.
[into phone] Hi, Senator. Why don't you take your legislative agenda and shove it up your ass. He closes the phone as the crowd applauds again. He turns back to everyone.
Turns out I was fine. He tosses phone to Donna, who catches it as we--

Scenes.Scene Heading: SMASH CUT TO: MAIN TITLES.
FADE IN: INT. THE WHITE HOUSE BRIEFING ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: C.J. is fielding questions from a roomful of reporters. They are all clamoring for C.J.

Dialogues.Line: C.J.? Is the White House concerned that the FEC will become a partisan political football?
I'd like to emphasize again that the President has nominated one Democrat and one Republican, which he was, certainly, under no legal obligation to do. There's more clamoring.
Jesse.
In the past, the F.E.C. Commissioners were chosen...
In the past, the F.E.C. Commissioners has been chosen by the President, signing off on whomever the Congressional Leadership pointed to.
Was the Congressional Leadership aware in advance that the President would be slipping this announcement in his speech tonight?
I think it's possible we forgot to tell them.
C.J., is the President declaring war on Congress?

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh is watching the press conference on TV.

Dialogues.Line: Say it's a police action.
[on T.V.] The President isn't empowered to declare war. The President is empowered. In fact, he's obligated to nominate Federal Agency Directors. I call it more of a police action.
[chuckles] How 'bout that?
[enters] Toby wants you.
On the phone? They walk out of the office into JOSH'S BULLPEN AREA.
In his office.
Do you know why?
Polling.
He's bringing in Al Kiefer?
Let him tell you.
Why can't you tell me?
'Cause you're going to his office right now. And I've got 37 different things to...
[huffily] Fine. He leaves and she follows into the HALLWAY.
Josh.
Yeah.
Yes, he's bringing in Al Keifer.
It's a big polling week, Donna. I figured he was bringing in Kiefer.
Okay.
That's what you were afraid to tell me?
I wasn't afraid.
Okay.
The thing is, and it's going to be interesting to see how you react to this, but Kiefer wants to bring in a California expert.
That's a good idea, cause... wait... [pause, looks]
Yeah.
Joey Lucas.
She's coming out with Kiefer tomorrow.
Okay... okay....
By the way, that's what I was afraid to tell you.
You... you shouldn't have been. You know why?
It's no big deal.
It's no big deal. And I'll tell you what else.
You're a pro.
I... I am a pro. But that's not what I was going to say.
What were you going to say?
That's what I was going to say.
Yeah.
But, both those things are true. I'm a pro and what was the other one?
It's no big deal.
That's right. They walk into the COMMUNICATIONS OFFICE.
Rambo! There's a small applause.
You talking to me?
Nice phone call.
That's how we do things in New England, my friends. [raises is arms in victory]
In Indiana, we're not allowed to talk like that.
In New Jersey, we encourage it.
Where's Toby?
They're in Sam's office. Josh enters SAM'S OFFICE. Sam is typing at his desk. Toby is standing looking over Sam's shoulder. Josh shuts the door and sits on a chair.
Hey.
[to Josh] Hang on. [to Sam] That's good... good... Okay... Sam?
Yeah.
You're going to come to a verb soon, right?
Okay. You know what this is called?
Bad writing?
Imagery.
Well, you say potato... Josh, it's a big polling week. I'm bringing in Al Kiefer.
You've turned 180 degrees on Kiefer. You know that?
I haven't turned on Kiefer at all. I don't want him advising the President. I want him bringing us numbers.
Advising people is what pollsters do.
He'll do what I tell him to do. Also....
English as the National Language.
That's the first thing they're going to fight back with, Josh.
We need Hispanics. You know what state has a large population of Hispanics?
Uh... I want to say Maine, but uh...
California.
California. Damn, and I was only off by a continent.
Josh.
It's fine. Bring her out here.
She'll be here tomorrow.
This isn't a thing.
Okay.
I met her twice, Toby.

Yeah, but, one of those times, she broke your heart. You know the way women can do. Where they take your heart and they throw it on the floor and then they stomp on it with their big high heals. She's a very beautiful and interesting woman. I can see why a lot of guys would go for her. [pause] You know, there's nothing at all I'm saying now of any value. So, I think the thing to do is... I think I should just keep writing.
Okay. [gets up] We had a good night.
Yeah.
[at the door] C.J.'s doing great in there. He leaves. Toby is still looking over Sam's shoulder.
Any time you want to use punctuation, that'd be fine.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. BRIEFING ROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: The press clamors for C.J.

Dialogues.Line: I'm going to take one more question. Katie.
The Federal Elections Commission's role has never been that much more than symbolic...
I wouldn't say the F.E.C. was merely symbolic, but if you're suggesting they're toothless, I'll agree with you.
Given that, does the White House think that two new commissioners will make any difference?
No.
Then why do it?
Symbolism. There'll be plenty more tomorrow. Everybody have a good night. The reporters clamor for C.J. but she heads off to Carol near the door.
Carol. She whispers. Carol walks to a reporter, JACK, who is sitting in front of Danny.
Jack, C.J.'s inviting you back to follow up on a couple of things.
Me?
Yeah.
She doesn't want me. [turns to Danny] She wants Danny.
No, she asked for you.
Danny -- The Senior White House Correspondent. If there's going to be an exclusive with the Press Secretary...
Go. She wants you. C.J. glances at Danny before she leaves the room.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: EXT. WASHINGTON D.C. STREET - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Sam and Toby are crossing a street.
Mandatory Minimums are racist.
I understand that.
They're a red herring.
I understand that, too.
It's a way of looking like you're tough on crime, without assuming the burden of being tough on crime.
Everything you've said I understand.
I'm saying...
We do things one thing at a time.
But I'm saying we don't have time to do things one thing at a time.
We're talking about treatment.
I'm talking about treatment and I'm talking about Mandatory Minimums and I'm saying it's a red herring and I'm saying it's racist.
When you talk to the President, I want you talking about treatment. I want you talking about treatment vs. enforcement and I don't want you to stray from that!
Toby, is this what you meant when you said, "Sam, you're completely in charge of this"?
Yes, I meant, you're in charge of this, in the sense that you're subordinate to me in every way. [stops walking and looks around] Where is this place?
What place?
The breakfast place.
It's still on the last street.
Why didn't you say anything?
We were having a nice conversation. Toby looks a bit annoyed and heads back in the other direction.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. AN OUTDOOR PATIO - DAY
Scenes.Description: Leo is seated at a table and Margaret is standing beside him.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. McGarry, would you like some tomato juice while waiting for the others?
Thanks, Celia. MARGARET is still standing fussing with some #2 pencils She sits down and fusses a bit with her place settings.
All set there?
Yeah. Josh and Donna enter the patio area.
Leo. We couldn't meet closer to the office?
I don't want people coming by the table.
We couldn't meet in the office?
I was hungry.
We couldn't have food ordered?
Oh, sit down, would you?
You should notice that Josh has on a nice suit.
That is a nice suit.
Donna.
We'll call it his Joy Lucas suit....
Donna.
...you know from now on.
Joey Lucas is coming?
We need a California expert and this is my regular Tuesday suit.
You assign your clothes days of the week?
I'm saying there's no particular M.O. behind... Toby and Sam enter.
Found it.
About time. Sit down.
Ah, Leo....
Hang on. [to Toby] Talk to me about drugs.
We can make a case for treatment vs. enforcement and we're ready to go to the President. A cell phone rings.
We're also ready to go to the President with Mandatory Minimums on crack versus powder cocaine.
One step at a time.
That's what Toby just said.
Toby's right.
Yes, but does anyone remember that I was put in charge.
It was an honorary kind of thing, Sam.
Leo. [hands Leo the cell phone]
[into phone] Yeah.
[to the others] Are you ready to order?
[to Margaret] Write these names down: Dalton, Dawson, Foxworthy, Greer, Morgenthau, Stackhouse, and Sugarbaker. [into phone] Thank you.
What was that?
You know what that was.
Leo, what do you want me to do with this thing?
Hold on to them until I say so.
It's exactly the right thing to do.
From anybody but me.
I'd like to clear up that I... I don't have suits for the days of the week. This is just a regular suit.
It's a nice suit.
Sure, it's a nice suit. It's his Joey Lucas....
Donna!
I'm beginning to regret not getting the waffles.
[exasperated] I am beginning to regret having hired any of you. We have a 42% job approval and you're talking about waffles and something with Josh, I don't understand.
He's wearing a special suit for Joey Lucas.
You got dressed up for a guy named Joey?
Joey... Joey Lucas is a woman... and I'm not getting dressed up for her.
It's his regular Tuesday suit.
My point is... we have to make it through the week without making any mistakes.
We will.
I'm saying that this is...
I'm saying calm down.
I'm perfectly calm.
You're not calm, Leo. You're acting like a nervous hooleelia. Everyone looks at Sam.
A what?
It may not be a word. It may just be something my mother used to say.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Toby, C.J., Josh, Sam, Leo, Bartlet, and Al Kiefer are sitting in various seats.

Dialogues.Line: It's a huge mistake.
Al...

It is a huge mistake, Mr. President. And possibly a fatal one. It'll doom the midterms in November. It'll haunt you at the convention. And if you manage to get renominated, which is far from a lock, there's no way you'll win reelection.

Al's Mr. Good News Happy Guy. Bartlet smirks. Al Sam. For the first time, more voters disapprove than approve of the President's job performance, 42% approval. This is not the time to come out for legalization.
We're not coming out for legalization. Mandy enters. Both C.J. and Toby move towards her. C.J. ushers Mandy out of the Oval Office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: It's going to be a long day.
Mandy.
Kiefer's just getting warmed up.
Listen... C.J. gives Mandy a knowing look.
You're kidding.
No.
He doesn't want me in there?
Leo's not comfortable with it.
Leo's not comfortable with it.
No.
I want to talk to the President.
You can't.
You can't.
It was just a memo.
It wasn't just a memo.
The fact that you guys....
Do you have any idea how pissed people are at you?
They're pissed at me, that's how pissed they are at you. They want to know how the hell I didn't know about the memo.
I can be trusted.
We'll see. There's plenty for you to do. Leo would feel more comfortable if you stayed out of this...
Okay. Okay! [walks away in a huff]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: You're coming...
Drug control...
Mr. President.
Listen to me...
Sir.
Listen to Sam.
Drug control appropriations...
...which total 17.6 billion...
...are divided into a ratio of 2/3 enforcement, 1/3 treatment. We want to reverse that ratio.
Spend less money on drug enforcement?
So that we can spend more money on treatment.
So, you're soft on crime.
Al...
You don't care if kids shoot up on the playground at recess.
We don't care do we, Sam?
No, sir.
[enters] What'd I miss?
Kiefer's been here 45 minutes, he's already got me on the playground at recess.
[to Al] Took you 45 minutes?
Mr. President, Sam and I have been working with the Office of National Drug Control Policy, we have some numbers you should hear. Charlie comes in and catches Josh's eye. Josh gets up and leaves.
Let's hear 'em.
5,642 Federal prisoners... Josh and Charlie reach the OUTER OVAL OFFICE.
What's up?
Joey Lucas is here. She's waiting in your office.
Okay.
Okay. As Josh closes the door, he looks at something on Mrs. Landingham's desk. He notices Charlie looking at him, smiling.
What are you smiling at?
Fine lookin' woman, Josh. They start to walk out.
Yes.
I could help you out.
Help me out with what?
She's a fine looking woman.
Stop saying that!
I owe you a lot, Josh. You got me this job. I'd like to pay you back.
By helping me out?
By helping you out.
What makes you think I need any help?
She's a fine looking woman....
Get away from me. Charlie turns and heads back to the Oval Office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh enters.

Dialogues.Line: Hey, Joey. Hey, Kenny. Good to see you. I got your desks set up out here. Why don't you come with me? [walks out]
Hey!
Yeah.
My flight was fine, thank you. They reach JOEY'S OFFICE.

Joey, we're in a bit of a mode here and I think it's best if we just do business. Plus, this is the White House. I wouldn't expect candy and flowers on your arrival. Margaret enters carrying some flowers.
Excuse me. Joey? These are from Leo McGarry. [presents her with flowers] He says welcome and let him know if there's anything you need.
Well, that's so sweet. Thank him for me.
I will. Did you have a good flight?
[a bit sternly to Margaret] Go back to your office.
They're carnations.

This is your desk. You got a phone. You got a computer. You got access to a staff. I know how women like to personalize their desks with flowers, and plants, and hand lotion, but I prefer the place to be professional.
Your staff likes to decorate their desks with hand lotion?
Some of them might, and I'm saying we don't do that on my side of the building. [pause] I'm going to go back to this meeting and then I'll brief you on what I need.
Okay. Josh leaves. Joey follows him out into the hall.
I'm not sleeping with Al Kiefer anymore. Josh abruptly stops in his tracks and turns to face Joey. The staffers all stop and gawk at Joey and Josh.
Come here. [motions to Joey]
Can I help you?
Yes!
How?
By coming here! He motions for her to approach him. She walks toward him.

This is a place where solemn work is done. This is a place... this is a place... let me say this... this is not a place where one's personal things... where things among people... this is not a place... let's... This is a place where work is done and nothing else.
You bet.
Okay. [turns to leave]
Nice suit.
[pauses to look at her] I'll... I'll be back. C.J. suddenly catches up with Josh. They stop in the lobby.
Josh, listen. I misspoke last night. I said the President nominated a Democrat and a Republican, even though he was under no legal obligation to do so. It turns out he is.
[sighs] C.J....
I know.
This from the White House counsel?
Yeah.
You sure?
About what?
You said he nominated a Democrat and a Republican.
Even though he was under no legal obligation to do so. Yeah, I just looked at the transcript.
All right. You'll fix it at the briefing?
Yeah.
Don't worry about it. [leaves C.J. standing in the lobby]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. PORTICO - DAY
Scenes.Description: Two Marine Guards salute each other. We follow one of them as he marches. The camera pans from outside into the Oval Office through the glass double doors.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - CONTINUOUS

Dialogues.Line: The American Medical Association says that addiction is a disease.
You're not going to be able to sell that.
Al!
You're not going to be able to sell it.
The A.M.A. says it, why does it he have to sell it?
Because...
Drug addiction is a disease. It's a... it's... it's a... medical problem. It can be treated. This isn't ideological. It's science.
It's science to you.
[big sigh] Science is science to everybody, Al.
[enters] What'd I miss?
Toby was just explaining to Al that science is science to everyone.
And I believe that science is science to everybody. I just don't think you can sell that.
I'm sorry, Mr. President. While Al tries to come up with something easier to sell than science, would you mind if I spoke to Toby and Leo alone?
Go. Before Josh leaves with Toby and Leo, he gives Al an odd look.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Josh, Toby and Leo enter.

Dialogues.Line: So...
Yeah.
Hey, Joey Lucas says she's not with Kiefer anymore.
Well that's a load off our minds.
Yeah... uh... C.J. misspoke last night during her briefing... uh, she'll fix it when she gets back in there.
What did she say?
She said the President nominated a Democrat and a Republican when he was under no legal obligation to do so.
He is under a legal obligation.
She knows that now.
This is just the kind of dumb mistake we don't need right now.
She knows that, too.
All right, what are you gonna do?
How's it going in there?
Sam's just starting.
You talked to him about the thing, yet? [pointing at Toby]
No.
Me?
Yeah, listen....
We want you to go to a meeting.
With who?
A prominent House Democrat who has a voice on Campaign Finance Reform and if it was someone on the Ethics Committee that'd be even better, cause then she could answer some of Leo's questions.
[pause, smiles a bit] I used to be married to someone who fits that description.
I set up lunch for the two of you.
You set me up on a date with my ex-wife?
Yeah. Let her know the President's not going to ask the democrats to unilaterally drop soft money.
Make that clear.
And also take her temperature on the ethics thing.
Okay. He looks back and forth at Leo and Josh before heading back to the Oval Office.
See ya later. [starts to leave but turns around] Leo, you had to send flowers?
It's a nice thing to do.
Yeah, but I had this whole patter thing going... and then... the hell with it. [exits]
Margaret!
[comes in] Yes.
The list of names I gave you before?
Dalton, Dawson, Foxworthy, Greer, Morgenthau, Stackhouse, Sugarbaker.
You didn't have to memorize them.
I couldn't help it.
Okay.
My mind works that way.
Yes, call their offices. I want to see one representative apiece at two o'clock. I want them as a group.
In the office?
In the press briefing room. [walks toward the door]
Leo.
Yeah.
What do those seven people have in common?
Don't worry about it. He enters the Oval Office and closes the door.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. JOEY'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Josh enters. Kenny tries to get Joey's attention of Josh's arrival.

Dialogues.Line: Hello.
Hello.
I see you're all settled in.
Ah, yes, yes.
Area looks good. Not too many personal items. Got your little clock, that's fine.
Thank you.

Here's the story. The President announced last night, he's naming two Campaign Finance Reform minded nominees to the F.E.C. This will anger the Republican Leadership to the extent they'll retaliate. Retaliate, how? They'll introduce a series of bills design to put the President on the wrong side of public debates. The first will be a law making English the National language.
I already know this, Josh. I've been working on it since Toby called me.
Joey... Joey's alarm clock rings.
Lunchtime. Kenny and Joey take off. Josh leans back in his seat.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE OVAL OFFICE - DAY

Dialogues.Line: Over 30% of the entire Federal prison population are non-violent first time offenders in jail for drug related crimes.
Sam...
At a cost, for those prisoners alone...
Sam!
...of 2 million dollars a day.
Mr. President, we can sell the public on the idea that 2 million bucks a day can be put to better use.
Not if it's for treatment.
Yes, if it's for treatment. Yes, we can demonstrate that treatment is what prevents substance abuse.
And yes, if you can get people to sit still long enough to hear that argument. But, it takes a lot less time to hear "Just Say No" And anyone on the other side is soft on crime.
The A.M.A....
Can't sell it!
Can't sell science?
Mr. President.
I'm hungry and so far nobody has convinced me of anything.
Let's go eat lunch and meet back here in an hour.
Yes, sir. TOBY and LEO Thank you, sir. Bartlet, Sam, Leo and Toby disperse in all directions, leaving Al alone in the Oval Office.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. HALLWAY - CONTINUOUS
Scenes.Description: Sam leaves the Oval Office and meets up with Cathy.

Dialogues.Line: Hey, Sam. How's it going?
Uh, we're in the early stages.
Do you know what you want for lunch?
That's an interesting question.
Sam.
I could have turkey.
Sam.
I could have some fish.
Would you like to look at the menu?
A nice piece of fish never hurt anyone, Cathy. Sam enters his office to find Steve Onorato waiting for him.
Hey, Sam.
Steve.
There was an O.M.B. meeting downstairs. I wanted to see you. They said you were with the President that I should wait here.
Yes. This is about the F.E.C. nominees?
Ah, look...
You don't want to see me, you want to see Josh.
I was hoping you and I could talk.
On the F.E.C., Josh is the guy.
Josh isn't quite himself lately.
Steve.
"Take your legislative agenda and shove it up your ass"?
That sounds exactly like Josh to me.
My boss is ready to set the building on fire.
Then your boss will be arrested, as I'm quite sure that's against the law.
Look, don't mess with me Sam, I'm serious.
And I'm tired, and this isn't my thing. Go see Josh.
You gonna eat?
What?
Lunch. Are you gonna eat?
Yeah, but at my desk, I was just gonna get...
What are you having?
Turkey.
Get two. He takes off his jacket and sits down. Sam looks a little off-balanced at being ambushed by Onorato.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. A PARK NEAR THE TIDAL BASIN - DAY
Scenes.Description: Congresswoman ANDREA WYATT is sitting on a picnic blanket. Toby is standing nearby.

Dialogues.Line: It's a beautiful day.
Yes.
This is nice. It's like a picnic.
There are restaurants, you know, indoors, with waiters and tables.
You should come sit next to me. [pats the blanket]
I'm wearing a suit.
So am I.
I'm a responsible adult.
I'm a member of the United States Congress.
I rest my case.
You know what I got?
What?
I got pie. [pulls out a Tupperware container from her bag]
Andy.
Toby, I've got really good pie. It's homemade. [takes a piece of the pie and eats it]
You baked a pie?
No, I didn't mean I made it in my home.
Let's go.
[puts the Tupperware in her bag] This pie was baked for me by one of my constituents.
And you trust it?
Well, that's why I was hoping you'd eat it first.
Andy. She gets up and picks up her blanket. Toby and Andy start to walk by the Tidal Basin.
Want to talk about the F.E.C.?
The President's not gonna ask anyone to give up soft money unilaterally.
You're still going to hear from Stadler and Ross.
Yeah.
Probably from McCovey, Lester, Brock...probably Klesko, Trask...
Ritchie.
Yeah.
But we have your people in line?
Yeah.
What about drugs?
That's a different story.
Andy...
Mandatory Minimums are racist.
One step at a time.
It's part of the same step.
Treatment.
I'm saying Mandatory Minimums... They each try to talk over one another.
I know what you're saying. I don't want to talk about Mandatory Minimums.
The Sentencing Commissioners...
Andy, I don't want to...
...proposals regarding cocaine recommend that relative federal mandatory minimums sentencing crack users...

This is what happens. This is what you do. I say I don't want to talk about Mandatory Minimums and we talk about Mandatory Minimums anyway. You hijack my ability to make that decision for myself, Andrea. And making decisions for myself is my birthright!
Good to get that off you chest there, Pokey?
Yes.
Okay.
You don't have a problem with what Leo's gonna do?
No, but I want to be there.
Why?
Just for fun.
It's not fun, Andy.
Okay.
It's not fun...
Okay.
Not everything is fun....
Okay!
If you want to be there, you can be there, but this is a serious thing.
Can I bring my pie?
Andy.
I'm just saying it's a serious thing. There might not be any food there.
Can you walk faster, please? I really don't like to be outdoors this long. Andy speeds up her pace a bit to keep up with Toby.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. SAM'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: Sam is arguing with Onorato while eating lunch.

Dialogues.Line: The fact is we'll probably have to confirm your nominees.
[mouthful] Yeah.
They're too qualified.
They're too qualified?
Too qualified not to confirm.
That's a problem.
I'm saying, there's no political cover.
I understood what you're saying.
So my question is....
Steve, the F.E.C. nominees aren't my thing.
I'm not talking about the F.E.C. now. I'm talking about drugs. You're gearing up to announce a new drug policy.
We've been gearing up for 14 months.
Yeah, but now you're taking daylong strategy sessions in the Oval Office.
Yeah.
Drugs are obviously important to you.
Important to everyone.
I mean, particularly to you. You've been the point man at the White House.
Yeah.
So why do you want to trade it in for a move on campaign finance? It's not going to get you anywhere.
It's gonna get me somewhere and I'm not trading it in.
You are.
We're not bartering.
I'm saying without the F.E.C. nominations, there's room to work with us.
And with the nominations?

You can have all the strategy sessions you want. No one you need's gonna take your phone call. And you, Sam, can go back to writing speeches for when the President meets the Girl Scout who sold the most cupcakes. Cathy knocks on Sam's door and enters.
Sam.
[to Onorato] Cookies.
Huh?
[takes his jacket and heads out] Girl Scouts sells cookies, not cupcakes. And it was a pretty good speech, I wrote. It was about volunteerism.
Well keep up the good work, Sam.
[from outside his office] I will.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. LEO'S OFFICE - DAY
Scenes.Description: C.J. enters. Leo is signing something in his table.

Dialogues.Line: Leo.
Yeah.
I was just coming to see you.
I don't have much time.
You're people are here. They're in the press briefing room.
Okay. [heads out as C.J. follows]
Carol's keeping the press in the northeast lobby. She'll wait for your high sign.
I'll be over in a minute.
We're telling anyone who asks why the press is out of there that it's a special event.
Good.
Leo, I don't know if you've heard...
Yeah, I did hear C.J. You want me to tell you how many different ways that screw-up was stupid?
I know.
For one thing, don't pass yourself off as a legal authority. For another, what the hell are you doing using a phrase like "under no legal obligation"?
Leo.
You're parsing at a time when the whole idea...
I know.
So right out of the gate, we've got to go back.
Yes.
These amateur mistakes make me crazy, C.J.
Yes.
I'll be in there in a minute. He exits through a door leaving C.J. alone in the hallway.
That was bush league. Danny, who was talking to several reporters down the hall, is now walking towards C.J. They head for her office.
That was bush league what you did last night.
We'll talk in my office.
And why can't anyone go in the Press Room?
There's a meeting in there.
What kind of meeting?
None of your business.
It's the Press Room. They walk by Carol's desk.
Hi, Carol.
Hi, Carol.
Hi. C.J. and Danny enter C.J.'S OFFICE. C.J. shuts the door.
Don't talk to me like that in front of people.
Look...
No! I just got called amateur twice in 10 seconds. The White House Chief of Staff can do it to me wherever he wants. You don't do it in front of people.
If I don't have access anymore, I don't have a job.
I would think a man with your credentials...
You think I'm kidding around?
[yells] You think I am?!
The memo was news.
Says you.
That's right. Says me -- says me, says my editor, says every paper who picked it up the next day. Says Time, says Newsweek...
Congratulations, you're a movie star. You're also on the outside looking in for a while, so get used to it.
Used to it? I'm paid for it, and what you don't understand....
DON'T tell me what I don't understand! I'm not in my freshman year anymore. I understand more than you think.
[knocks] C.J.?
Yeah.
Leo's on his way in.
Thanks. [leaves]
What's going on in the Press Room?
Special event.

Scenes.Scene Heading: FADE IN: INT. PRESS ROOM - DAY
Scenes.Description: Seven people are sitting around. Leo enters. C.J. and Carol are guarding the doors.

Dialogues.Line: Good afternoon. I'll make this as quick and direct as I can. There's a chance...
Why are we in the Press Room?

This will be pretty fast, Stuart. Faster still if I'm not interrupted. There's a chance that a debate is about to begin over the best way to fight the drug problem in this country. The White House, being among those, who believe more money should be put into treatment. The people you work for, being among those who believe we should put more money into prisons. Andy and Toby quietly enter from the back and sit.
Leo, why the 7 of us?
Dick, in July of '96, your boss's son was arrested for carrying 25 grams of cocaine. That's a crime that usually carries... what Toby?
Eight to 15 years.
And what did the Congressman's son get?
Six months house arrest.

Lynn, your boss's husband was caught stealing Vicodin and Percocet from the hospital at which he served as Chief of Thoracic Surgery. Now, Vicodin and Percocet are schedule-two drugs in the same legal category as Opium. What was the blue-book value, Toby?
Each stolen pill carries the penalty of one year in prison and a monetary fine.
And what did we have for the Congresswoman's husband?
He went to a pre-trial diversion program. There's no longer any criminal record.
That's not bad.
Leo, I...

Stuart, yours is my favorite. Your boss has a daughter who was pulled over with 31 grams of coke and charged with intent to deliver. More over, she's just been indicted by a federal grand jury in Greenville, South Carolina, along with 18 other people for conspiracy to distribute. Toby...
She paid a fine of $2800 and forfeited her car in which the drugs were found.
The President wants a lively debate. Leo gives C.J. a signal. C.J. signals to Carol.

He wants to hear opposition, but he's not gonna stomach hypocrisy. We start hearing "soft on criminals", "soft on drugs" from any of the people you work for, we've got 7 stories ready for page one. C.J. and Carol let the press into the room.
You're saber-rattling.
Here comes the White House Press Corps. Let's find out.
We're done here. All seven people get up to leave.
You play the full nine innings at this level, Stuart. Tell your friends about it.
[to the press] Take your seats, please. C.J. will start the briefing. We follow Andy and Toby as they come out of the Press Room into the HALLWAY.
[sighs] Can I tell you something?
Listen.
Watching you guys do that....
Andy.
It was a little fun.
That was not fun.
You should've had some pie.
I have to get back to work. And you, being a Congresswoman... I'm sure you need to be back out there... you know, screwing the people.
I should tell you something.
What?
In the interest of full disclosure.
What?

The other night, I was out on a date. We had a couple glasses of wine. He pulled the car up, bumped the guy ahead of us. The cop was there. He was going to give him a blood-alcohol test, but then he recognized me.
That's fine.
I'm just saying....
You didn't say, "Officer, I'm a member of Congress, isn't there anything we can do about this?"
No.
Who were you out with?
A guy named Victor Stipe.
Executive advisor for the Orioles?
Yeah. They stop walking.
You went out on a date with the executive advisor for the Baltimore Orioles?
Toby, are you upset that I went out on a date? Or are you upset that I went out on a date with someone who plays in the same division as the Yankees?
Honest to God, I'm not sure. They enter TOBY'S OFFICE.
Mandatory Minimums, Toby.
What are you doing getting into cars with guys that have been drinking? They start talking at the same time again.
Cause I'm a grown woman....
That's what taxicabs are for.
And I will get into whatever car....
And also, I can still do that.
[stops and stares at Toby] You'd come pick me up with a date?
If it wasn't an Oriole, absolutely. Or a Red Sock. In fact, just date the National League, would you? He pauses as they stare at each other.
Toby, I'm not kidding. Mandatory Minimums.
Go away.
It's good seeing you. She plays a bit with Toby's lapels and gets ready to leave.
Andy?
Yeah.
Let me have the pie. Andy sighs and hands him the Tupperware with the pie and walks out the door smiling the whole time. Toby stands a bit at the door and watches her go.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: 11:30 P.M. Bartlet is asleep. Some books are scattered on the bed. There's a knock on the door. Leo enters the dark room.

Dialogues.Line: Mr. President.
[groggily] Yeah.
Oh, you're in bed?
Yeah.
When I called, you were awake.
Well, yeah, that's cause I answered the phone. [turns on the lamp]
I was just coming by to talk. It can wait.
What's on your mind? [waves for Leo to come in]
You sure?
Yeah, I got to be up in four hours, anyway.

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. JOSH'S OFFICE - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Josh is working at his desk. Charlie knocks and enters.

Dialogues.Line: Hey.
Hey. What are you doing?
F.E.C. Where's the President?
He went to the residence about an hour ago. So, I couldn't help noticing coming over here that the light in Joey Lucas's office is on.
She's still here?
Yeah.
Why are you telling me?
She's a fine looking...
Charlie.
Okay.
Have a good night.
You give her a little something.
Yeah.
"Here this is for you, cause it's your first day. You don't know anybody." Bam -- you give it to her. You say something nice.
[waves to Charlie] See you tomorrow.
Take it easy. He leaves as Sam and Toby enter.
Hey, Charlie.
Hey.
[to Sam] Tell him what you told me.
See... uh... I still don't understand.
Tell him what you told me.
Steve Onorato came to see me this afternoon. We had lunch.
Onorato came to you?
Yeah.
Tell him what he said.
He said that if we dropped F.E.C., he could warm things up for drugs. Josh and Toby start snickering.
I don't understand.
He said that?
He even pointed out to Sam that Sam was working on drugs for the White House.
[grinning] You made the big time, Sam.
What's going on?
He knows about Laurie.
What do you mean?
He knows you're friends with a call girl.
What does that have to do with anything?
He wants to move you out to the front of the field so he can drop Laurie on you.
Are you serious?
Yeah.
Are you serious?!
It's okay, Sam. You haven't done anything wrong.
Oh, I know I haven't done anything wrong. Are you serious?
[chuckling] We're serious. Don't worry about it.
He... are you saying, he... he tried to practice on my...
...credulous simplicity?
Yeah.
Yeah.
Alright. I want to know what I can do right now.
Sam.
No, right now! At 11:35. I want to know what I can do.
Take it easy.

I won't take it easy! Give me the phone. [reaches for the phone] I'm gonna call the Senator and I'm gonna tell him that he can shove his legislative agenda up his ass! Toby and Josh try to restrain the phone from Sam.
I've already done that.
I'll do it again.
You know what this is like? This is like The Godfather. When Pacino tells James Caan that he's gonna kill the cop. It's a lot like that scene, only not really.
Did Leo go home?
He's... he's still here somewhere.
He's in the Residence.
It is like that scene. I'm James Caan. [to Sam] You're...you're Al Pacino.
Let's go.
Toby, you're the guy who shows Pacino how to make tomato sauce.
[to Sam] Let's go. They all leave JOSH'S OFFICE.
I'll be right behind, I'm gonna pick up the late wires. He pauses and stares down the hall toward JOEY'S OFFICE. He enters while hiding something behind his back.
Hello.
Hi.
Hey, Kenny.
Hey, Josh.
I saw the light was on. You guys are here late.

I wanted to give you first look analysis in the morning. There's really some decent models in Marin County and the Bay Area. But San Jose is a mess and so is Orange County, Long Beach, Anaheim, and San Diego.
I brought you a coffee mug.
Why?
Just as a thing, cause you don't know anybody. It's got... uh... a picture of the White House. It says, 'The White House.' Seal of the President. It's a White House coffee mug.
Thank you.
Kenny, can you give us a second?
Oh, sure. [signing to Joey] I'm going to step outside. [walks away]
I wore this suit, special today. This isn't my regular Tuesday suit.
You have a regular Tuesday suit?
No.
For me?
Yeah... So... Okay, I gotta go. [smiles wide as Josh leaves]

Scenes.Scene Heading: CUT TO: INT. THE PRESIDENT'S BEDROOM - NIGHT
Scenes.Description: Leo is sitting next to the President's bed.

Dialogues.Line: So... I don't want to be Labor the point, though. I... I do think this is understandable. I feel a little self-conscience coming down the mountain on drugs two months after I announce I was a recovering drug addict. What do you think?
About what?
What I just said.
Well, I wasn't listening to a lot of it.
Sir...

Leo, if there's anyone qualified to talk about the benefits of treatment vs. criminal action, it's you. Is there anyone whose life would be better right now, if you'd had gone to jail instead of rehab?
No.
Thank you. Is there anything else? Someone knocks.
Apparently there is.
[enters] Mr. President.
Yeah.
I'm sorry. I heard Leo was here, I assumed you were awake.
I am.
I haven't seen you all day, I just... wanted to apologize for the gaffe at the briefing last night.
You fixed it this afternoon, right?
Yeah.
Then let's move on.
I do apologize, sir.
No need to apologize, but I accept your apology and now I'm ready, if not eager, to move on. There's another knock. Sam and Toby enter.
Mr. President?
How you doin'?
You were sleeping?
Not for a little while now.
This is... I say, this is great, Mr. President, because usually you have a hard time getting to sleep before one or two.
Not tonight.
That's got to feel good.
Guys, let me tell you what I would like to have happen, right now.
[enters] Good evening, Mr. President.
Josh walking in the door wasn't even close.
How you doing, tonight?
I'm fine, thanks. How you doing?
Good! I gave Joey Lucas a coffee mug. She doesn't know anybody here and she's already working hard. She's very committed. I think I did the right thing.
See, the part I don't understand is, I got like, 24 armed guards right outside my bedroom door...
Mr. President, after a day of meetings, are you any closer to a decision on drugs?

I'm a day closer. There'll be more meetings tomorrow. In the meantime, everybody calm down. Leo's got your engines fired like you're running Daytona. That's fine. Keep them there. Guess what? Mistakes are gonna be made. Minimize them, fix them, move on. Kiefer's numbers got you scared? Listen to me. I have never lost an election in my life. We do this right, people are going to respond. You all had a good day.
We should go and leave you now.
You guys should feel free to do this when my wife is here. All chuckle.
Sir, something has come up and frankly, it's got me as hot as a pistol. Apparently....
Sam.
We can talk about this tomorrow.
Everybody. Mandy was doing her job. It's time to let her out of the doghouse.
That's me.
[to Leo] She was doing her job. C.J.?
Yes, sir.
So was Danny.
Yes, sir.
Good night. Everyone says their good nights. Sam, Josh, and C.J. leave.
Mr. President.
We were almost done.
I... met with Congresswoman Wyatt today.
When you were married to her, did you call her Congresswoman Wyatt?
No, sir.
Sometimes I call my wife, Dr. Bartlet.
I call her Andy or uh... Andrea.
Okay.
Mandatory Minimums.
You're whupped, my friend.
Sir.
No, she's been talking to your for a year about Mandatory Minimums. You've been saying no. Looks like we know who wears the pants in the Ziegler family.
You call your wife 'Dr. Bartlet'?
Just for the turn-on. Leo smirks.
Uh... the thing is, she's right.
Andy.
Mandatory Minimums are considerably higher for crack than for powder cocaine.
Yes.
The vast majority of crack users are black. The vast majority of drug users are white. The Mandatory Minimums are racist.
Yes, they are.
It should be part of the discussion.
And it will be.
Good... uh... good night.
Good night. Toby leaves.
[to Leo] I'm sleeping better. [beat] When I sleep, I dream about a great discussion with experts and ideas and diction and energy and honesty. And when I wake up, I think, "I can sell that."
Good night, Mr. President.
Good night. Leo shuts off the room lights and closes the doors. Bartlet shuts off his bed lamp and goes back to bed.

Scenes.Scene Heading: DISSOLVE TO: END TITLES.
